Dataset_Info.Funding_Info: NOAA Climate Program Office; NOAA Ocean Acidification Program

Variable.Description_of_Variable: Mole fraction of CO2 in the equilibrator headspace (dry) at equilibrator temperature (ppm)
Mole fraction of CO2 measured in dry outside air (ppm)
Mole fraction of CO2 in outside air associated with each water analysis. These values are interpolated between the bracketing averaged good xCO2_ATM analyses (ppm)
Barometric pressure in the equilibrator headspace (hPa)
Barometric pressure measured outside, corrected to sea level (hPa)
Sea surface salinity on Practical Salinity Scale (o/oo)
Fugacity of CO2 in air corresponding to the interpolated xCO2 at SST and 100% humidity (?atm)
Sea water fCO2 minus interpolated air fCO2 (?atm)
Quality control flag for fCO2 values (2=good, 3=questionable)
Quality control subflag for fCO2 values, provides explanation when QC flag=3

Equilibrator_Design.Location_of_Sea_Water_Intake: Sea chest under the engine room
Equilibrator_Design.Equilibrator_Type: Sprayhead above dynamic pool, no thermal jacket
Equilibrator_Design.Drying_Method_for_CO2_in_water: Gas stream passes through a thermoelectric condenser (~5 ?C) and then through a Perma Pure (Nafion) dryer before reaching the analyzer (90% dry).
Equilibrator_Design.Additional_Information: Primary equilibrator is vented through a secondary equilibrator.

CO2_in_Marine_Air.Measurement: Yes, 5 readings in a group every ~4.5 hours
CO2_in_Marine_Air.Location_and_Height: On mast above the bridge at ~20 meters above the sea surface

CO2_Sensor.Manufacturer_of_Calibration_Gas:
Std 1: CA3095, 247.01 ppm, owned by AOML, used every 4.5 hours.
Std 2: CA3880, 318.94 ppm, owned by AOML, used every 4.5 hours.
Std 3: CA5979, 381.89 ppm, owned by AOML, used every 4.5 hours.
Std 4: CA6380, 448.29 ppm, owned by ESRL, used every 4.5 hours.
CO2_Sensor.CO2_Sensor_Calibration: The analyzer is calibrated every ~4.5 hours using ESRL standards that are directly traceable to the WMO scale. Ultra-High Purity air (0.0 ppm CO2) and the high standard are used to zero and span the LI-COR analyzer.
CO2_Sensor.Environmental_Control: Instrument is located next to a walkway in the engine room.
CO2_Sensor.Method_References: Pierrot, D., C. Neil, K. Sullivan, R. Castle, R. Wanninkhof, H. Lueger, T. Johannessen, A. Olsen, R. A. Feely, and C. E. Cosca (2009), Recommendations for autonomous underway pCO2 measuring systems and data reduction routines, Deep-Sea Res II, 56, 512-522.

Sea_Surface_Temperature.Location: From Beginning to 16 Nov 2011, a SBE48 (Magnetic Hull mounted) sensor was used. It was located on the wall of the sea chest.
Sea_Surface_Temperature.Other_Comments: Manufacturer's Resolution is taken as Precision.

Equilibrator_Temperature.Location: Inserted into equilibrator ~ 5 cm below the water level.
Equilibrator_Temperature.Other_Comments: Manufacturer's Resolution is taken as Precision.

Equilibrator_Pressure.Location: Attached to equilibrator headspace. Combined with Licor Pressure
Equilibrator_Pressure.Other_Comments: Differential pressure reading from Setra-239 attached to the equilibrator headspace was added to the pressure reading from the LICOR analyzer to yield equilibrator pressure. Manufacturer's Resolution is taken as Precision.

Atmospheric_Pressure.Location: On deck above bridge at ~20 m above sea surface.
Atmospheric_Pressure.Other_Comments: Manufacturer's Resolution is taken as Precision.

Sea_Surface_Salinity.Location: In the ship's engine room next to CO2 system.
Sea_Surface_Salinity.Other_Comments: Manufacturer's Resolution is taken as Precision.

x_tags.Additional_Information:
Atm P shows large swings of about 8 mbar.
EQU gas flow was close to 0 most of the time. However there is indication that the headspace gas still circulates (xCO2 seems to vary normally). Around JDay 207-208, the spread of xCO2 values increases and occasionally an xCO2 value will be off by ~20-30 ppm for undetermined reasons (unrelated to changes in P, T, licor voThe frequency of these outliers increases with time, which casts doubt on the validity of the data.
